DataElement.preferredName: Clinical Trial Eligibility Criteria Prior Therapy Other Than Radiation Chemotherapy or Gliadel Wafer Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Indicator of whether patient has had any prior therapies other than radiation, chemotherapy, and Gliadel wafers.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Clinical Trial Eligibility Criteria Prior Therapeutic Procedure Other Negation Radiation Therapy Chemotherapy Polifeprosan 20 with Carmustine Implant Administered
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Characteristics which are necessary to allow a subject to participate in a clinical study, as outlined in the study protocol. The concept covers inclusion and exclusion criteria.__Earlier in time or order._An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process._Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned._An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction._Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation._The use of synthetic or naturally-occurring chemicals for the treatment of diseases._A synthetic, biodegradable wafer containing the agent carmustine with antineoplastic activity. Used to deliver drug directly into a brain tumor site and typically implanted post-surgically, the wafer is made of a biodegradable poly-anhydride copolymer and contains the nitrosourea carmustine.  As an antineoplastic nitrosourea, carmustine alkylates and cross-links DNA during all phases of the cell cycle, resulting in disruption of DNA function, cell cycle arrest, and apoptosis.  Carmustine also carbamoylates proteins, including DNA repair enzymes, resulting in an enhanced cytotoxic effect.  Carmustine is highly lipophilic and crosses the blood-brain barrier readily. (NCI04)_The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Characteristics which are necessary to allow a subject to participate in a clinical study, as outlined in the study protocol. The concept covers inclusion and exclusion criteria.

Concepts.definition: Characteristics which are necessary to allow a subject to participate in a clinical study, as outlined in the study protocol. The concept covers inclusion and exclusion criteria.

Property.preferredName: Prior Therapeutic Procedure Negation Radiation Therapy Chemotherapy Polifeprosan 20 with Carmustine Implant Administered
Property.preferredDefinition: Earlier in time or order.:An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.:An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.:Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.:The use of synthetic or naturally-occurring chemicals for the treatment of diseases.:A synthetic, biodegradable wafer containing the agent carmustine with antineoplastic activity. Used to deliver drug directly into a brain tumor site and typically implanted post-surgically, the wafer is made of a biodegradable poly-anhydride copolymer and contains the nitrosourea carmustine.  As an antineoplastic nitrosourea, carmustine alkylates and cross-links DNA during all phases of the cell cycle, resulting in disruption of DNA function, cell cycle arrest, and apoptosis.  Carmustine also carbamoylates proteins, including DNA repair enzymes, resulting in an enhanced cytotoxic effect.  Carmustine is highly lipophilic and crosses the blood-brain barrier readily. (NCI04):The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

Concepts.definition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.
An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.

Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.
The use of synthetic or naturally-occurring chemicals for the treatment of diseases.

A synthetic, biodegradable wafer containing the agent carmustine with antineoplastic activity. Used to deliver drug directly into a brain tumor site and typically implanted post-surgically, the wafer is made of a biodegradable poly-anhydride copolymer and contains the nitrosourea carmustine.  As an antineoplastic nitrosourea, carmustine alkylates and cross-links DNA during all phases of the cell cycle, resulting in disruption of DNA function, cell cycle arrest, and apoptosis.  Carmustine also carbamoylates proteins, including DNA repair enzymes, resulting in an enhanced cytotoxic effect.  Carmustine is highly lipophilic and crosses the blood-brain barrier readily. (NCI04)
The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: trial-specific criteria that a patient must meet to be enrolled.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual domain that includes value meanings to be used for Indicator Value Meanings such as Yes, No, Unknown, No Applicable

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of either yes or no.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Has the patient had any prior
ReferenceDocuments.description: Has the patient had any prior therapies other than radiation, temozolomide, and Gliadel wafers (placed during the first surgery at diagnosis of GBM).

ReferenceDocuments.name: ABTC 1603
ReferenceDocuments.description: Has the patient received prior radiation therapy, chemotherapy, immunotherapy or therapy with biologic agent (including immunotoxins, immunoconjugates, antisense, peptide receptor antagonists, interferons, interluekins, TIL, LAK or gene therapy), or hormonal therapy for their brain tumor?

DataElement.changeDescription: Created for 1501 study in Rave per request by R.Marasigan. mc 2/4/2016
